awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The O2/N2 Ratio and CO2 Airborne Southern Ocean (ORCAS) Study
awd_abstract_narration:
The Southern Ocean plays a dominant role in the oceanic uptake of excess (anthropogenic) carbon, yet the extent of this air-sea exchange process is poorly represented by earth system models, and its future projection remains highly uncertain. The O2/N2 Ratio and CO2 Airborne Southern Ocean Study (ORCAS) seeks to advance understanding of the physical and biological controls on air-sea exchange and uptake of O2 and CO2 in the vast Southern Ocean. This will be investigated through intensive airborne surveys of atmospheric O2, CO2, related gases, their state of equilibrium, along with other ocean surface properties over diverse biogeochemical regions adjacent to the southern tip of South America and the Western Antarctic Peninsula. 

ORCAS will utilize the NSF Gulfstream V (GV) aircraft equipped with a suite of high-precision in situ and remote sensing instruments, on 14 flights over a period of 6 weeks in austral mid-summer, from Punta Arenas, Chile, out over the Drake Passage, and with concurrent overflights of the ARSV LM Gould sampling the Palmer LTER site. ORCAS observations will be guided by, and used to test a suite of ocean biogeochemistry models to improve our understanding of key processes and feedbacks in this under sampled yet climatically important region of the world.

por.por_cntn:
We know that the Southern Ocean is responsible for a sizable fraction of the total ocean uptake of human-emitted CO2, but we do not understand the processes controlling this uptake well enough to predict their behaviour in the future. The O2/N2 Ratio and CO2 Airborne Southern Ocean (ORCAS) Study was an ambitious effort to expand our observational insights and state of knowledge concerning the biogeochemical drivers of Southern Ocean carbon exchange. The primary effort and most significant accomplishment of the first year of the project was the successful completion of an intensive airborne survey of atmospheric O2, CO2, related gases, and ocean surface properties over diverse biogeochemical regions adjacent to the southern tip of South America and the Antarctic Peninsula in January and February of 2016. The NSF/NCAR Gulfstream V aircraft flew 96 research hours based out of Punta Arenas, Chile, while carrying a full payload of cutting-edge atmospheric and oceanographic research equipment. Much of the work in the second year of the project focused on analyzing additional gases in collected whole air samples, and processing and quality controlling all of the field data, culminating in their public release at the end of February 2017. During this time and since, the ORCAS science team and a growing population of external collaborators have worked to analyze the results with comparison to models and other studies, to develop robust conclusions about the physical and biological controls on air-sea exchange of O2, CO2, and other gases in the Southern Ocean, and to disseminate these results through presentations and publications.

One of the surprises from the ORCAS field measurements was the magnitude of the CO2 depletion we observed in the atmospheric boundary layer over the Southern Ocean, which was a factor of 2 greater than we expected from prior climatological estimates. Our analyses of this feature have focused on using models to put it in a broader spatial and year-to-year variability context, and to evaluate its implications for our understanding of the air-sea CO2 exchange in the region. We have found that the ORCAS CO2 gradients are generally consistent with an increase in Southern Ocean CO2 uptake relative to the late 1990s, speculated by others based on pCO2 measurements.  Additionally, we have determined that atmospheric profiles of CO2 provide an important constraint for understanding Southern Ocean CO2 fluxes. 

Another primary observational result from ORCAS is that the O2:CO2 ratio of the atmospheric gradients was consistently negative, indicating a clear dominance of biological over thermal forcing of summertime Southern Ocean CO2 fluxes. This result is interesting because state-of-the art Earth system models currently disagree on the seasonal phasing of these CO2 fluxes and which process, biological uptake or outgassing as a result of surface warming, is the strongest driving force. We have been able to establish the link between these atmospheric O2:CO2 ratios and those of the underlying ocean fluxes, such that they can be used to discriminate among divergent Earth System models and air-sea flux climatologies.

The ORCAS data set is very rich, with well over 100 chemical species, aerosol and cloud properties, and ocean color observed on 96 hours of flights. In addition to the work on CO2 and O2 exchange, the science team has applied ORCAS measurements to assess model predictions of clouds over the Southern Ocean, to improve understanding of short-lived reactive gases important for atmospheric chemistry, and to develop methods for remotely observing the productivity of algae. ORCAS CO2 measurements have also been useful in evaluating global carbon budget calculations, and are also being used to evaluate satellite based measurements of total column CO2. The ORCAS project also included training of 2 graduate students and 5 post-doctoral scholars, and included production and sharing of educational and outreach materials through the project web page and outreach events.

ORCAS Project web page:

https://www.eol.ucar.edu/field_projects/orcas
